Roll over the picture above to see a description of the parts of the Daisy 853C air rifle

 

The RSO must check an air rifle for safe operation before it can be used on a range. Rifles should be inspected at the firing point after the range is set up, and with the red flag/light showing (indicating the range is in use). Click here to read the criteria for Safe Rifle status on and off the range.

 

Click here for full Daisy 853C full specifications. For more details on air rifle operation and maintenance, refer to the Cadet Marksmanship Program Reference Manual  A-CR-CCP-177/PT-001.

 

A RSO is expected to know how to handle an air rifle safely, and how to resolve common malfunctions.  

Check Air Rifle Operation

Butt Plate (End of the butt). It is part of the rifle directly in contact with the marksman’s shoulder. It is adjustable in length with the addition of butt spacers (plastic inserts that can be added or removed).

Stock. Complete wooden portion of the rifle (from the butt plate end forward);

Sling. It is made of nylon and links the rifle to the marksman’s arm and supports most of the weight of the rifle.  

Trigger. Movable device that releases a spring and sets off the rifle mechanism to fire the pellet.

 

Trigger Guard. Metal area that surrounds and protects the trigger.

Safety Catch. This is a mechanism that, once engaged, prevents the rifle from firing by locking the trigger in place. It is a cross bolt type device located on the trigger guard. The black side indicates that the rifle is unable to fire (therefore, the safety is "on"); the red side indicates the rifle is ready to fire (therefore, the safety is "off").  

Bolt. Metal lever used for opening or closing the rifle mechanism. It must be in the closed position in order to fire.  

Pump Lever. Metal lever used to compress the air required to fire the pellet.  

Front Sight. Global front sight that uses aperture inserts.

Rear Sight. Micrometer sight adjustable for windage (left or right) and elevation (up or down). It is attached to the metal rail located above the action and can be adjusted forward or back.

Muzzle. Front end of the barrel equipped with attachable barrel weight.

Feed Track. Breech area where the pellet is inserted manually onto the single pellet adapter or with a five (5) pellet clip.

 

Chamber. Place where the pellet is held before firing.

Common air rifle malfunctions

Improperly maintained pump piston -  An air rifle that is hard to pump may indicate that the pump piston foam wiper has dried out. Completely open the pump lever, look for the marking close to the point where the lever attaches to the rifle that indicates “OIL HERE” and place one drop of SAE 30 oil. Try the lever to see if this improves performance. Do not saturate the piston with oil as this can also cause the pump to become hard to operate.

Jammed chamber -  A jammed chamber can be caused by closing the bolt too quickly and jamming a pellet into the chamber, or when a pellet is inserted backward into the chamber.   This can normally be fixed by following the same process as clearing an obstructed barrel

 

Seized bolt -  A seized bolt can be caused when a pellet is accidently inserted into the receiver assembly through the opening for the bolt handle, causing the moving parts inside to jam (the bolt won’t open or close completely). These pellets are usually loose and can be cleared manually (place the safety in the ON position, then turn the rifle upside down and shake).

 

Broken valve.  A broken valve may produce a hissing sound, indicating that it is not holding air in the valve body.  It may also cause the cadet air rifle not to fire because no air is being compressed. Worn seals (“o-rings”) in the pump or valve assembly can also allow cause a decrease in air pressure and produce a hissing sound.

Check air rifle operation

 

1.  Inspect the general condition of the rifle, check sights for damage or loose mounting screws and ensure the butt plate screws are snug;

2.  Pump the rifle but don’t load a pellet;

3.  Check the breech area then cock and dry fire the rifle;

4.  Place the safety catch in the “On” position;

5.  Open the bolt and insert the safety rod the barrel
(check that it is visible in the breech); and

6.  Place the rifle pointing downrange in preparation
for the participant (see picture below).

Safe Rifle Status

 

The RSO must be able to easily determine that an air rifle is unloaded and safe. Any time that an air rifle is not in use, it should be placed down or stored meeting the criteria for safe rifle status.

Safe Rifle Status Criteria

On the firing point:

Off the firing point:

•Bolt is open

•Bolt is open

•Safety catch ON

•Safety catch ON

•Pump handle open 5-8cm

•Pump handle open 5-8cm
 

•Safety rod is inserted and visible in the breech
